questions.question_text: Which license is required to use the Palo Alto Networks built-in IP address EDLs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/policy/use-an-external-dynamic-list-in-policy/built-in-edls
An active Threat Prevention license is required to obtain Palo Alto Networks built-in EDLs. These built-in EDLs protect your network against malicious hosts

Selected Answer: A
Panorama Administrator's Guide
Manage Locks for Restricting Configuration Changes
Locking the candidate or running configuration prevents other administrators from changing the configuration until you manually remove the lock or Panorama removes it automatically (after a commit). Locks ensure that administrators donâ€™t make conflicting changes to the same settings or interdependent settings during concurrent login sessions.

Correct Answer is D
Local Configuration Locks: Local configuration locks are used to prevent changes from being applied to a managed device while a configuration is being edited or committed. These locks can prevent conflicts between local and Panorama configurations.

Manual Unlocking: From Panorama, administrators can manually unlock a device if there are local configuration locks. This is useful when you need to override or clear these locks remotely

Selected Answer: B
In the context of "panorama managed devices" i think a local configuration lock is a lock placed on a firewall config locally, by logging on to it, rather than logging on to panorama.

If any lock placed by another administrator, in panorama or locally on a firewall. Would simply be unlocked by a commit done in panorama by any administrator, it's purpose would be defeated.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. Once lock from local PA, new policy cant be push from Pano

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. Once lock from local PA, new policy cant be push from Pano

B is correct: https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000CltACAS "When a user has a configuration lock, it is not possible to perform a commit or push a policy from Panorama. If the administrator is not available to remove the lock, a device WebGUI or CLI command can be used by a superuser to force the removal of the configuration lock."

A is not correct. You can't perform a commit while a lock is in place, therefore, the lock can't be automatically removed after a commit that you cannot execute.

B is correct. If you trey to push a config to a device with a local local you get the following message:
 Details:
 . Other administrators are holding device wide config locks.

Selected Answer: B
local locks prevent panorama pushes. they have to be removed by the admin who locked it

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Panorama managed devices?

choices.B: Local configuration locks prohibit Security policy changes for a Panorama managed device.
choices.A: Panorama automatically removes local configuration locks after a commit from Panorama.
choices.C: Security policy rules configured on local firewalls always take precedence.
choices.D: Local configuration locks can be manually unlocked from Panorama.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: C
Security Profiles are added to the end of Security policy rules. After a packet has been allowed by the Security policy

questions.question_text: A Security Profile can block or allow traffic at which point?

choices.B: after it is matched to a Security policy rule that allows or blocks traffic
choices.A: on either the data plane or the management plane
choices.C: after it is matched to a Security policy rule that allows traffic
choices.D: before it is matched to a Security policy rule

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Place the following steps in the packet processing order of operations from first to last.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Zone Protection Checks
 TCP State Check
 Forwarding (based on interface type)
 NAT Policy Lookup (only L3 & Virt wire)
 DoS Protection Policy Lookup
 Security Policy Lookup
 Session Allocation
Firewall Session Fast Path (if packet from existing session)
 Security Processing
 Captive Portal
Application Identification
Content Inspection
Forwarding/Egress (includes QoS)

comments.content: Thanks! better than PA official guide!

I think after Content Inspection, there will be
Encrypt/Decrypt
Security Profile enforcement

discussion.content: Correct Answer

questions.question_text:
Employees are shown an application block page when they try to access YouTube. Which security policy is blocking the YouTube application?
//IMG//

discussion.content: D is Correct.

D is indeed correct answer.
You can check application categories on:
https://applipedia.paloaltonetworks.com/

D is correct, why? Interzone default applies here; it is a predefined security rule in Palo Alto Networks firewalls that block all traffic between different zones. It is displayed at the bottom of the security rule base and can be overridden by a user-defined rule. The interzone-default rule has a deny action and applies to any traffic that does not match any other rule in the rule list.

Selected Answer: D
The default Rule
D is correct. Remember Security Policies are a match condition, and then action is applied to the matching traffic.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, B will filter Google Docs only

Selected Answer: D
D works

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Google is in a completely different classification than YouTube, owned or not. Also, there is no dependency in AppID. Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D inter-zone default.
D is correct because this is google-doc base not google base
Yes D. I tested on my LAB the answer B can't block youtube.

comments.content: The application on the policy is google-docs-base. As it is different from google-base, B cannot be the right answer. D is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B- Because Youtube depends on Google-base
